title: Joseph Duquet
text:
Joseph Duquet (September 18, 1815 – December 21, 1838) was a <a href="civil%20law%20notary">notary</a> in <a href="Lower%20Canada">Lower Canada</a>. He was executed for his part in the <a href="Lower%20Canada%20Rebellion">Lower Canada Rebellion</a>.
He was born in <a href="Ch%C3%A2teauguay">Châteauguay</a>, Lower Canada in 1815. He studied at the <a href="Petit%20S%C3%A9minaire%20de%20Montr%C3%A9al">Petit Séminaire de Montréal</a> and the Collège de Chambly. Duquet articled as a notary with <a href="Joseph-Narcisse%20Cardinal">Joseph-Narcisse Cardinal</a> and then studied law with <a href="Chevalier%20de%20Lorimier">Chevalier de Lorimier</a>. In 1837, he continued his training as a notary with his uncle <a href="Pierre-Paul%20D%C3%A9maray">Pierre-Paul Démaray</a> at Dorchester (later <a href="Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu">Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu</a>). Démaray was arrested for <a href="high%20treason">high treason</a> in November 1837 but was freed by a group of Patriotes while he was being escorted to the jail at <a href="Montreal">Montreal</a>. Duquet helped his uncle escape to the United States. After a skirmish at Moore's Corner, he escaped to <a href="Swanton%20%28town%29%2C%20Vermont">Swanton, Vermont</a>. In February 1838, he took part in an attempted invasion of Lower Canada by <a href="Robert%20Nelson%20%28insurrectionist%29">Robert Nelson</a>.
Duquet returned to Lower Canada in July 1838 after an amnesty was proclaimed. He then helped recruit members for the <a href="fr%C3%A8res%20chasseurs">frères chasseurs</a> and organized a lodge at Châteauguay. He was captured with Joseph-Narcisse Cardinal at <a href="Kahnawake">Kahnawake</a> when they attempted to get weapons from the native people there. At a trial in November 1838, he was sentenced to death for the crime of high treason with a recommendation for executive clemency. He was hanged at Montreal in December 1838 and buried in the old Catholic cemetery there. In 1858, his remains were moved to the <a href="Notre%20Dame%20des%20Neiges%20Cemetery">Notre Dame des Neiges Cemetery</a> and buried under a monument dedicated to the Patriotes of 1837–8.
